title: 110_hr5513
content: The Act is titled the "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" and aims to strengthen state laws regarding tobacco product sales to individuals under the age of 18. The Act "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" requires states to have laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18, and restricts minors from purchasing, receiving, or possessing tobacco products in public places. The Act "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" mandates that law enforcement agencies notify parents or guardians if a minor is caught purchasing or possessing tobacco products in public. Retailers must also inform their employees about the prohibition of selling tobacco products to individuals under 18. The Act prohibits the purchase or possession of tobacco products by individuals under 18 in public places. Employers can avoid violation by verifying age or implementing a compliance program. Violators may face penalties and community service. Some states have delayed applicability due to legislative sessions. The Act prohibits tobacco purchase by under 18 in public places, with penalties and community service for violators. Some states delay enforcement due to legislative sessions. States must set goals to reduce retailer violations annually. The Act sets limits on the percentage of violations relative to inspections each fiscal year, gradually decreasing from 20% in 2010 to 10% in 2020 and beyond. States must enforce laws to reduce underage access to tobacco products as part of funding agreements for grants. The Act requires states to conduct random inspections to ensure compliance with laws restricting underage access to tobacco products. States must also submit annual reports to the Secretary detailing enforcement activities and the success in reducing availability of tobacco products to individuals under 18 years of age. The Act mandates states to conduct random inspections to enforce laws limiting underage access to tobacco products. States must submit annual reports outlining their success in meeting goals and reducing availability to individuals under 18 years old. Funding agreements for grants under section 1921 allow states to engage individuals under 18 for compliance testing with parental consent and direct supervision. Additionally, states must certify the use of settlement proceeds for grants under section 1921. The State must certify the use of settlement proceeds for grants under section 1921 and comply with regulations to receive funding. The Secretary determines state compliance with specific requirements before granting funds, with potential reductions for noncompliance. The Secretary may reduce the allotment under section 1921 if the State fails to comply with subsections (a), (b), or (c) by 10%, 20%, 30%, or 40% depending on the fiscal year. The Secretary may reduce the allotment under section 1921 for a State if it is not in compliance with certain subsections, by up to 40% of the determined amount under section 1933 for the fiscal year. Additionally, assistance will be provided to States in implementing State laws by the Secretary. The Secretary will provide assistance to States in implementing State laws by developing model legislative language and offering technical guidance. The term 'first applicable fiscal year' is defined, and the effective date for the amendment is specified. The provisions of section 1926 of the Public Health Service Act shall apply to fiscal years preceding the first applicable fiscal year. The term "first applicable fiscal year" is defined in subsection (g) of section 1926. SEC. 3. PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF INGREDIENTS. Amendment to the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act requires the Secretary to make ingredient information accessible to the public online within 48 hours of receipt.
